newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Non-Aligned Movement rejects U.S. certification.
newsitem.headline: Non-Aligned Movement rejects U.S. certification.

text.p: The Non-Aligned Movement criticised the annual U.S. drug certification process Monday, saying it violated the group's basic principle of non- intervention in the affairs of independent states.

The United States on Friday "decertified" Colombia -- chairman of the movement since 1995 -- for the second consecutive year on the grounds that it had failed to prove itself a trustworthy ally in the global fight against drugs.

"The Movement rejects the continuing use of unilateral mechanisms of evaluation, qualification and certification, since these are inconsistent with the principles of equal sovereignty of states and non-intervention," said a statement from Colombia's foreign ministry, issued in the name of all 113 Non-Aligned member countries.

It added that Non-Aligned countries -- who compromise a majority in the United Nations -- were jointly committed to fighting against any "coercive and unilateral policies" that might be imposed by industrialised northern countries on the developing or underdeveloped South.
The five other countries on the U.S. drug blacklist, Afghanistan, Burma, Iran, Nigeria and Syria, are also members of the movement.
Countries decertified by Washington as part of an annual process required by the U.S. Congress face an immediate cutoff of most U.S. aid and possible trade sanctions.
